ARTICLE.TITLE: Virgin Atlantic files for bankruptcy amid coronavirus pandemic
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Virgin Atlantic has filed for bankruptcy in the United States as it claims it will run out of cash next month without a rescue deal.

The cash-strapped airline filed for Chapter 15 bankruptcy protection in New York, a move that allows a foreign company with US assets to protect itself from creditors as it works to secure a private rescue plan.

The move coincides with its stablemate Virgin Australia’s unrelated announcement it will axe 3000 staff – about a third of its workforce – and ditch Tigerair Australia under its plan to emerge from voluntary administration.

London-based Virgin Atlantic, which is co-owned by Richard Branson’s Virgin Group and US airline Delta, has been particularly hard-hit by the COVID-19 pandemic as it flies only long-haul routes.

It suspended all its passenger operations in April, closing its London Gatwick base and cutting 3500 jobs, and only resumed some flights last month.

RELATED: Follow our live Victoria coronavirus updates

RELATED: Tigerair Australia to be killed off

media_camera Virgin Atlantic has filed for bankruptcy in the US.

The pandemic has seen Virgin Atlantic’s reservations drop about 89 per cent on last year, with demand for the second half of 2020 only a quarter of what it was in 2019.

This week Virgin Atlantic told a London court it risked running out of cash by September if it didn’t secure approval for a £1.2 billion ($A2.2 billion) rescue package announced last month, Bloomberg reported.

The airline said without the rescue funds, its available cash would drop below the amount specified in bondholder contracts, which could force it to sell its Heathrow Airport slots and trigger its collapse.

Virgin Atlantic obtained approval to convene meetings of affected creditors to vote on a restricting plan on August 25.

The airline said it needed to recapitalise “to not only survive the exigent threats posed by the COVID-19 global pandemic but to thrive once the immediate global health crisis passes,” Reuters reported.

media_camera Virgin Group founder Sir Richard Branson. Picture: Don Emmert/AFP

Richard Branson had drawn criticism for calling on governments – both in the UK and Australia – to help his airlines survive the pandemic.

In April, the billionaire wrote a lengthy open letter warning Australia faced a Qantas monopoly if Virgin Australia, which was 10 per cent owned by the Virgin Group, disappeared.

In a development unrelated to Virgin Atlantic’s woes, Virgin Australia announced today it would shed 3000 jobs and axe its low-cost subsidiary Tigerair Australia as it planned to re-emerge “stronger, more profitable and competitive” from voluntary administration.

The jobs will be cut across cabin crew, ground crew, engineers, baggage handlers and some international head office staff.

media_camera Virgin Australia will let go of 3000 workers as it emerges from voluntary administration. Picture: Tertius Pickard/NCA NewsWire

Virgin Australia chief executive Paul Scurrah said the airline would focus on domestic and short-haul international flights, although those overseas destinations have not been confirmed.

“Demand for domestic and short-haul international travel is likely to take at least three years to return to pre-COVID-19 levels, with the real chance it could be longer, which means as a business we must make changes to ensure the Virgin Australia Group is successful in this new world,” Mr Scurrah said.

“Our initial focus will be on investing in the core Virgin Australia domestic and short-haul international operation alongside our 10-million-member strong Velocity Frequent Flyer program, continuing to offer an extensive network of destinations, a domestic lounge network and value for money for customers.”

Originally published as Virgin Atlantic files for bankruptcy
